tn.ref: Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Sidonians, and Hittites
tn.text: These are names of people groups. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The word "Now" is used here to mark a break in the main storyline where the narrator starts to tell a new part of the story.

tn.ref: turn your heart to their gods
tn.text: To "turn someone's heart" is to convince that person to change his affection. AT: "persuade you to worship the gods that they worship" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: seven hundred royal wives and three hundred concubines
tn.text: "700 royal wives and 300 concubines" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

To "turn someone's heart" is to convince that person to change his affection. AT: "turned his heart away from Yahweh" or "persuaded him to stop worshiping Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: his heart was not fully surrendered ... as was the heart of David
tn.text: To "surrender" your heart refers to giving total allegiance and affection. AT: "he was not fully devoted ... as was David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These are the names of false gods. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a people group. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: The phrase, "in the sight of" refers to someone's opinion. AT: "what Yahweh considered to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Milcom" is perhaps another name for the idol "Molech." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of false gods. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: sacrificed to their gods at them
tn.text: Here the words "at them" refer to the shrines that Solomon built.

tn.ref: his heart had turned away from him
tn.text: The words "his heart had turned" refer to his having changed allegiance and affection. AT: "Solomon had stopped worshiping Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he had appeared to him twice
tn.text: "Yahweh had appeared to Solomon twice"
To "tear from" is to forcefully remove. This is like a person tears apart a piece of cloth. AT: "forcefully take the kingdom from you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "hand" refers to control, authority and power. AT: "your son's control" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: When David was in Edom ... since Hadad was still a little child
tn.text: This is background material that happened long before.
The words "all Israel" refer to the army of Israel. AT: "Joab and all of the Israelite army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: But Hadad was taken with other Edomites by his father's servants
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. "But the servants of Hadad's father took him with other Edomites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This section continues the background information that began in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:11:14|11:15]].
Here the word "They" refers to Hadad and the other Edomites mentioned in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:11:14|11:17]].
These are the names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: David laid down with his ancestors
tn.text: This is a polite way of saying David was dead. AT: "David died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the name of locations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"David" refers to all of David's forces. AT: "when David's army overcame" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here the word "days" refers to a period of time and "Solomon" refers to everything under his control. AT: "all the time when Solomon had control" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"Rezon hated Israel very much"
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of locations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: lifted up his hand against the king
tn.text: The word "hand" refers to authority, power and control. The phrase "lifted up against" refers to having opposed someone by using authority, power and control. This is a metonymy used as a common idiom. AT: "rebelled against the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Solomon built up the place at Millo
tn.text: Translate "Millo" as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:09:15|9:15]].
Possible meanings are 1) "a great warrior" or 2) "a very capable man" (UDB) or 3) "a wealthy and influential man"
"he made him commander"
The word "labor" refers to the work that Solomon commanded the people to do for his government. This is a metonymy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to the descendants of Joseph who were the people groups of Ephraim and Manasseh. This is a metonymy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The Shilonites are a people group. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here the word "He" refers to Ahijah.

Here "tear ... out" is a metaphor that refers to the action of forcefully removing. This is like a person tears apart a piece of cloth. AT: "forcefully take the kingdom out" See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:11:11|11:11]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "hand" is a metonym that refers to a person's authority, control and power. AT: "Solomon's control" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The name "Solomon" here is a metonym referring to his descendants. AT: "Solomon's sons will have" or "Solomon's descendants will have" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: what is right in my eyes
tn.text: "Eyes" here is a metonym for someone's opinion or idea. This is a commonly used idiom. AT: "what I consider to be right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
These are the names of false gods. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Ahijah continues to tell Jeroboam what Yahweh has said.
Here the word "I" refers to Yahweh.
Here the word "hand" is a metonym that refers to a person's authority, control and power. AT: "out of Solomon's control" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I will give it to you
tn.text: Here the word "you" refers to Jeroboam.

tn.ref: may always have a lamp before me
tn.text: The word "lamp" is a metonym that refers to a person's influence and guidance. AT: "will always have a descendant to rule as an influence and a guide for obeying my covenant with David's family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Ahijah continues to tell Jeroboam what Yahweh has said.
Here the word "I" refers to Yahweh and the word "you" refers to Jeroboam.

tn.ref: what is right in my eyes
tn.text: The word "eyes" here is a metonym for someone's opinion or idea. This is a commonly used idiom. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:11:31|11:33]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The clause "build a house" is a metaphor for establishing descendants from that time on. AT: "establish for you a lasting kingdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: are they not written in The Book of the Events of Solomon?
tn.text: This can be expressed in active form and assumes that the answer is positive. The question is rhetorical and is used for emphasis. AT: "you can find them in The Book of the Events of Solomon." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: The Book of the Events of Solomon
tn.text: This book no longer exists.

tn.ref: He slept with his ancestors and he was buried
tn.text: The clause "slept with his ancestors" is a metaphor that expresses as a euphemism the death of a person in more gentle words. AT: "He died and he was buried with his ancestors" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This can be expressed in active form. AT: "people buried him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
